The role of nanomaterials in electroanalytical biosensors: A mini review
Yong Zhang, Qin Wei ⁎ Key Laboratory of Chemical Sensing & Analysis in Universities of Shandong (University of Jinan), School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, China
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: sdjndxwq@163.com (Q. Wei).

Article history: Received 29 April 2016 Received in revised form 16 August 2016 Accepted 6 September 2016 Available online xxxx
Nanomaterials have beenwidely applied in the preparation of electroanalytical biosensors. Due to their small size effect, quantum size effect and surface and interface effect, nanomaterials can remarkably improve the important performance indexes of biosensors, such as stability, repeatability and sensitivity. Furthermore, as a result of different composition,morphology and size of all kinds of nanomaterials, they play the different roles in the process of the construction of the biosensors. In this review, the role of nanomaterials in electroanalytical biosensors used as the main line, a summary of 105 articles generalizes the main research achievement of electroanalytical biosensors.
© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. Keywords: Nanomaterials Electroanalytical biosensor Electrochemical biosensor Electrochemiluminescence biosensor Photoelectrochemical biosensor
1. Introduction
In recent decades, with the improvement of people life and social productivity, various detection assays have been developed to cope with the challenges of public security and medical test. Among kinds of newly developed analytical assays, the electroanalytical biosensors have numerous advantages, such as good selectivity, high sensitivity, fast analysis speed, low cost, etc. and also can realize on-line continuous monitoring in the complex system [1–5]. Furthermore, themicroelectrode in sensor fabrication offers new advantages including high mass-transfer rate, faster sensor response, and ease of integration for parallel analysis [6–9]. The application value of electroanalytical biosensors ismore andmore important in various fields, for example, food safety analysis, disease diagnosis, environmental monitoring and so on [10–14].
Based on the concept of the biosensor, the electroanalytical biosensors consist of two parts. One is recognizer component for specific identification of target analytes and the other is conversion component for conversion of response signals. According to the different classification criteria, electroanalytical biosensors can be divided into many different types. For example, based on the different mode of signals conversion, electroanalytical biosensors can be divided into electrochemical biosensors, electrochemiluminescence (ECL) biosensors, photoelectrochemical (PEC) biosensors and so on [4,15–17]. Depending on different sensing elements, electroanalytical biosensors can be divided into DNA biosensor, enzyme biosensor, immunosensor, cells biosensor, tissue, molecular imprinting biosensor and so on [18–21].Whatever types of electroanalytical biosensors, the key goal is to realize the optimization of various performance indicators.
he role of nanomaterials in el /j.jelechem.2016.09.011
Due to the special physical and chemical properties of nanomaterials, which can be used for improving the adsorption ability of molecules, the signal response speed and the stability of the modified electrodes, the main performance of electroanalytical biosensors, such as sensitivity, repeatability and stability, can be highly improved [22–24]. There has been tremendous growth in the field of nanomaterials-based electroanalytical biosensors.
Here, using the role of nanomaterials in electroanalytical biosensors as themain line,wediscussed the application and effect of nanomaterials for fabricating electroanalytical biosensorsmainly based on our group'swork in nearly five years.
2. Electroanalytical biosensors
An electroanalytical biosensor typically contains three components [25]: (1) the biological element recognizing analyte in the sample (e.g. DNAbiosensor, immunosensor, tissue-based biosensor, enzyme biosensor, etc.), (2) the transducer/detector element transforming the signal generated from the biological interaction into another signal which can be more easily measured and quantified (e.g. electrochemical biosensor, ECL biosensor, PEC biosensor, etc.), the associated signal processors primarily responsible for the display of the results in a user-friendly way (e.g. computer, microscopic observation, visual detection, etc.). Generally, different kind of electroanalytical biosensors based on the different mode of signal conversion have the common characteristics, which are fast analysis speed, good accuracy, high selectivity and sensitivity, etc. On the other hand, due the different transducer parts, whatever of electrochemical biosensor, ECL biosensor and PEC biosensor, has its own characteristics and advantages. Herein, we only discuss these three kinds of biosensors and the role of nanomaterials playing in them (Fig. 1 and 3).
ectroanalytical biosensors: A mini review, Journal of Electroanalytical
2.1. Electrochemical biosensors
Electrochemical biosensors are of special interest due to their analytical characteristics including operational simplicity, extraordinary sensitivity, low cost and rapid, real-time detection [26–28]. Furthermore, electrochemical biosensors can be prepared for pointof-care device [13]. In recent years, intensive research effort has been put into the design of novel electrochemical biosensors as well as the improvement of their performances [29–31]. However, the electrochemical biosensor still faces many challenges. For example, based on their inherent flexibility, sandwich enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA) have emerged as the method of choice for protein quantitation in clinical and research laboratories, but these heterogeneous assays require expert users with dedicated instrumentation, and they are time-consuming, laborious, and expensive [13]. To overcome the difficulties, as shown in Table 1, kinds of novel nanomaterials with excellent properties have been synthesized and applied in fabrication of electrochemical biosensors, which will be discussed in the following third parts.
2.2. ECL biosensors
ECL is a powerful analytical technique due to its high sensitivity, wide linear range, low background and simple instrumentation, which has been deeply studied and extensively applied to various fields including analysis of food or pharmaceutical, DNA-aptamer, immunoassay and so on. As for the ECL system (e.g. as shown in Fig. 2), two reaction procedures were included: the first step is the diffusion of generated reactive species from electrode and the second step is the emission of light which was induced by the reaction between electrogenerated substances and co-chemicals [32–34]. At present, the biggest challenge of fabricating ECL biosensor is increasing the efficiency of the core electron–hole recombination of nanomaterials and thus the luminescent emission, which can get high sensitivity for ECL detection [33]. For this purpose, as shown in Table 1, different kind of nanomaterials were used for preparation of ECL biosensors.
2.3. PEC biosensors
Like the ECL analytical technique, the PEC technique is also the evolutionary generation of the electrochemical method [3,35]. It also naturally inherits the advantages of the above techniques, such as low cost, simple instrumentation and high sensitivity. However, a great difference exists between them and the PEC technique offers some merits
Please cite this article as: Y. Zhang, Q. Wei, The role of nanomaterials in el Chemistry (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jelechem.2016.09.011
that could not be accomplished on the conventional platform. In PEC detection, light is utilized to excite the photoactive species and the electrical signal is transduced as the detection readout, which is the reverse of ECL [36]. Using two separate forms of signal for excitation anddetection, this technique possesses potentially higher sensitivity because of the reduced background associated with it [3,37–38]. Actually, for the detection of identical analytes with the same configurations, the PEC routes usually exhibit superior detection properties (e.g., lower detection limits) than their electrochemical counterparts [39]. Due to its desirable advantages and attractive potential in future biological analysis, the popularity of PEC bioanalysis has grown tremendously among the analytical community.
3. The role of nanomaterials
Over the past few decades, considerable advances have been made in electroanalytical biosensing area due to the tremendous progress in nano-research and the unique characteristics of nanomaterials [22,40]. The development of nanomaterials promotes the progress of electroanalytical biosensors in various aspects.
3.1. Selectivity promotion
On the basis of the chosen bio-recognition elements aiming at different targets, various electroanalytical biosensors have been proposed for particular analytical purposes. Themost two general models of the electroanalytical biosensors may be demonstrated by the simplest protocol of biotin–avidin recognition [3] and enzymatic biosensing. Whatever model of the electroanalytical biosensor, to immobilize the biomolecule, such as antibody, DNA, and enzyme, is the first challenge for fabricating biosensor. Considering the biological activity of the biomolecule, nanomaterials applied for biosensing should not only have large capacity of biomolecule adsorption, but also be biocompatible. According to the structure of nanomaterials, 0 dimensional (D), 1D, 2D and 3D nanomaterials play different roles for kinds of electroanalytical biosensors.
3.1.1. 0D nanomaterials Quantum dots (QDs) as the delegate of 0D nanomaterials are always applied for biosensors in twoways, i.e. modified on the electrode directly and modified on the DNA or antibody as the label. Whatever ways they are applied, 0D nanomaterials are used to get or enlarge the signal [41]. In general, QDs are made of elements in groups II-VI or III-V in the periodic table. They are known for their small size (1-10 nm) and size-dependent optical-electronic properties, low toxicity, environmental friendliness, low cost and facile synthesis [27]. As a representative of the typical QDs, CdS QDs can bemodified on the electrode to immobilize ds-DNA and due to the energy transfer, occurs between the excitons in the QDs and plasmons in the metal surface, the ECL properties of QDs near the metal surface could be improved significantly by adjusting the distance between nanostructural metallic surface and QDs [42].
Furthermore, due the high optical absorption coefficients, heterostructures based II–VI group compounds nanoclusters, e.g. CdX (X = S, Se or Te), are suitable materials used for fabricating thin-film photovoltaic device, solar cells and photo conductors. Although they have good photoelectron conversion efficiency, the rapid photo-generated electron–hole recombination rate of CdX results in a decrease in the photocurrent density. For getting high performance of PEC sensing device, we found ternary CdZnS thin films often exhibit improved chemical, structural and optical properties, and could be appropriate photoactive materials with high charge separate coefficients. We used them as an ideal photoactive material in PEC sensing for the detection of two metal ions on the same sensing platform [43].
However, Cd-containing QDs are always shown deleteriousness for biosensors. For reducing the toxicity of Cd-containing QDs, carbon
ectroanalytical biosensors: A mini review, Journal of Electroanalytical
quantum dots (CQDs) have been attracted intensive research interests recently [44]. For example, nitrogen-doped carbon quantum dots (NCQDs) were prepared by carbonization of diethylene triamine pentacetate acid (DTPA), and applied the NCQDs to immobilize Human IgG (HIgG) antibody via the reaction between carboxyl and amino group.
Besides QDs and nanoclusters, nanoparticles(NPs) are also play an important role in electroanalytical biosensors fabrication. Noble metal NPs, alloy NPs and metallic oxide NPs have different effects applying for electroanalytical biosensors due to the different components and morphologies [45]. Noblemetal NPs have been applied in electroanalytical biosensors on account of their good catalytic performance and biocompatibility [46].
For achieving the signal amplification of the biosensor, most of alloy NPs are composed of noble metals [47] or alloying noble metals with non-noble metals(Fe, Co, Ni, Cu etc.), which is an effective approach in enhancing the catalytic activity and sensitivity of nanomaterials [46]. The hollow ternary Pt/PdCu nanocubes with specific geometric structure own low densities and high surface areas which enable them to bindmore detection antibodies andhave superb electrocatalytic activity toward H2O2 reduction [48].
Metallic oxideNPs, such as Cu2O [49], Co3O4 [50], and Fe3O4 [51] etc., have less electrocatalytic performance toward the reduction of H2O2 than noble metal NPs, however they can reduce the cost of detection. So metallic oxide NPs also have been applied in the electroanalytical biosensing filed [32].

3.1.2. 1D nanomaterials Amino-functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes(MWCNTNH2) has good dispersity in water and is a promising support for massive loading of other nanomaterials or biomolecules, due to the hydrophilicity of primary amines [52]. Based on this, they can be utilized for supporting catalytic materials as labels for sandwich type electroanalytical biosensors [52].
Nanoneedles and nanorods were other familiar 1D nanomaterials. We prepared Ag2Se@CdSe nano-needles, which behaved high luminescent property. Making use of the cathodic ECL performance of Ag2Se@CdSe nano-needles to fabricate convenient, rapid and highly sensitive ECL immune modified electrodes, we evaluating the ECL performance of the Ag2Se@CdSe nano-needles by detecting CA72-4 concentration in human serum [53]. Nanorods sometimes show the special advantage due to their special structures. For example, we synthesized Au@Pd NRs with 30 nm, which is a balanced and appropriate size for combining antibodies, which can be explained by Rubik's cube theory [54].
3.1.3. 2D nanomaterials The immobilization of antibody on the electrode is important not only for ensuring loading enough antibody to realize selectivity but also for the increase of sensitivity of the immunosensor [55–57]. To consider the plane structure of the electrode, 2D nanomaterials might be the best choice [58–60].

Fig. 2. The schematic illustration of the label-free ECL immunosensor [32].
For fabrication of biosensors, graphene sheets (GS) is the representative 2Dnanomaterials,whichhas attracted a great deal of interest due to the high conductivity, good biocompatibility and electronic property [61–63]. We developed a one-pot methodology for the direct synthesis of mulberry like gold nanospheres (MGNS) supported on GS using aniline as a reducing regent. Additionally, the MGNS-GSs show a good and stable PEC property, and itmay have potential application in thefields of sensors and energy [64].
However, electrical conductivity of graphene cannot be completely controlled because it has no bandgap. Doping of graphene, which shows the possibility of opening the bandgap and modulating conducting types by substituting carbon atoms with foreign atoms, and the dopant atoms can tailor electronic band structure and the physicochemical property of graphene [65–66]. Especially, N-doped graphene sheets (N-GS), due to the high conductivity can increase electron transfer and sorption, which cause sensitive responsiveness and
thus the more satisfied detection limit, and we applied them in assembling EC biosensor for bisphenol A detection, ECL immunosensor for AFP detection, and PEC biosensor for fibroblast-like synoviocyte cell detection [65,67–69].
To further improve the water solubility of graphene, we synthesized NH2-graphene (NH2-G), as another functionalized graphene, with good solubility and excellent electronic properties [17]. In the fabrication of ECL biosensor for dopamine detection, the lower LOD could be gotten, which might be attributed that the conductivity of cationic polythiophene derivative was largely improved by adding NH2-G [70].
Graphite-like carbon nitride, g-C3N4, is a metal-free semiconductor and has the smallest direct band gap (2.7 eV) due to the p-conjugated graphitic planes formed by the sp2 hybridization of carbon and nitrogen [71]. G-C3N4 exhibits some excellent advantages, such as inexpensive, nontoxic and chemically/thermally stable, and can be prepared by a simple thermal pyrolysis method [72]. It is more important that g-
label-free PEC immunosensor [24].
Fig. 4. The schematic illustration of fabrication of ECL immunosensor based on MOFs porous materials as supporter [82].
C3N4may be a new class of efficient and promising luminophore for ECL sensing [73–74]. Based on this specialty, we also developed PEC aptasensor via g-C3N4 for the detection of Proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 6 gene [75].
Nanoporous gold films (NPG), made by selectively dissolution of silver from Au/Ag alloy under free corrosion conditions, are another 2D nanomaterials potentially applied for electrochemical analysis. NPG havemany other advantages, such as clean surface, good biocompatibility, large surface area, high surface-to-volume ratio, and tunable porosity [76]. Furthermore, the tunable porosity allows the convenient incorporation of biomolecules, such as antibody, and the good conductivity can enhance the electron transfer on the electrode surface, both of which amplify the electrochemical signal [77]. We applied NPG in modifying the electrode to immobilize antibody of cancer biomarkers and veterinary drug, and get good performance [76–78].
As a new type of two-dimensional nanomaterials, TiO2 nanosheets (NSs) has attracted more attention due to a large percentage of highly reactive {001} facets exposure and their enhanced photocatalytic activity than that of TiO2 NPs under ultraviolet irradiation [79–80]. So TiO2 NSs can be applied for PEC detection and get good performance [79].

3.1.4. 3D nanomaterials 3D nanomaterials can provide a higher surface area,whichwill bring some special electrochemical performance for the nanomaterials [81]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted extensive research interests in the field of sensing probe recently attributing to its special structure and properties [82]. As shown in Fig. 4, by means of the special type of porous materials, we applied cyclodextrins(CDs)based MOFs as the ECL sensing indicator in assembling a label-free and sensitive ECL immunosensing platform [82].
Another common 3D nanomaterial is semiconductor material, such as ZnO and 3D carbon materials etc. We employed 3D flower-like ZnO nanomaterials as the matrix and the label simultaneously in the fabrication of sandwich-type electrochemical immunosensor. As thematrix, 3D flower-like nanomaterials with the higher surface area can capturemore proteins. As the label, 3D flower-like nanomaterials with the higher surface area can produce better electrocatalytic performance. So the signal amplification strategy based on 3D flower-like nanomaterials in the fabrication of the designed immunosensor for CEA detection, low detection limit of 3.2 fg·mL−1was obtained [81]. Furthermore, comparedwith traditional immunosensors, immunosensors based on nanomaterials with special nanostructures and simple preparation methods would occupy
chemical immunosensor for detection of AFP [94].
ectroanalytical biosensors: A mini review, Journal of Electroanalytical
more advantages in clinical applications in future. Different kinds of 3D nanomaterials with simple preparation methods may be developed and employed in the fabrication of immunosensor.
3.2. Sensitivity enhancement
To improve the sensitivity of biosensors, the fabricating strategies have been developed by exploiting methods of signal amplification and signal enhancement [83]. In these strategies, the roles of nanomaterials are most played for immobilizing antibody, enzyme or DNA as labels and as the active materials to reduce the background signals.
For signal amplification, the strategy is always focused on step-bystep signal amplification. Have been used widely in fabrication of immunosensors for their numerous signal amplifications and excellent electrocatalytic effects [83]. Most researches are focused on such as the enzyme catalysis, the roll ring expansion of DNA, synergistic effect between different materials, and electrochemical reaction on the surface of electrode [84–86].
Horseradish peroxidase (HRP) is the most studied enzyme in electrochemical analysis field and always used as label for signal amplification. For loading it and maintaining its catalytic activity, many nanomaterials with good biocompatibility were prepared, such as noble metals, ferroferric oxides, mesoporous silicon dioxide [87–93]. For example, as shown in Fig. 5, a sandwich-type electrochemical immunosensor for quantitative detection of ɑ-Fetoprotein (AFP) was developed by using graphene sheets (GS) and thionine (TH) as a sensing platform and mesoporous silica nanoparticles (MSNs) loaded with ferroferric oxide (Fe3O4) nanoparticles and HRP as labels for a signal amplification strategy. Due to Fe3O4 nanoparticles have some intrinsic good catalytic activity toward H2O2. Fe3O4 nanoparticles and HRP as labels was taken into account for synergistic signal amplification. Moreover, HRP not only can enhance electrochemical signal as a biological enzyme but also can reduce nonspecific adsorption between the electrode surface and the label [94].
Additionally, metal ions as labels in immunosensors are also beneficial due to their highly sensitive electrochemical response and signals amplification capability [84–85]. From this point, we developed an ultrasensitive and multiplexed electrochemical immunoassay for estradiol and diethylstilbestrol which were immobilized onto GS due to π – π stacking. As shown in Fig. 6, amino-group functionalizedmesoporous Fe3O4 (Fe3O4-NH2) loaded with Pb2+ and Cd2+ were incubated with the estradiol or diethylstilbestrol antibodies with glutaraldehyde, respectively. The immunosensor was prepared by the immunoreaction between Ab and analytes. Under electrodeposition, Hg2+ was
Please cite this article as: Y. Zhang, Q. Wei, The role of nanomaterials in el Chemistry (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jelechem.2016.09.011
introduced to reduce themetal ions and form an amalgam. The amalgam was subsequently reoxidized to ions via a stripping analysis technique to achieve simultaneous detection [85].
The other strategies of signal amplification also have been paid attention by more and more researchers, such as external light sourcefree strategy for PEC immunosensor by using the chemiluminescence (CL) reaction as a light source [95], amicrofluidic paper-based analytical device equipped with a paper supercapacitor was integrated in the PEC immunoassay [96], paper-based and label-free PEC immunosensing device using CdS QD-ZnO-CNT nanocomposites [97] and so on. Recently, wemade efforts to develop dual amplification for fabricating biosensors [98–99]. For example, to detect carbohydrate antigen 72-4 (CA72-4), the polyaniline–Au asymmetric multicomponent nano-particles (PANi–AuAMNPs) were prepared through an interfacial reaction, which showed strong effect in catalyzing H2O2 reduction.With the secondary antibody (Ab2) adsorbed onto Au, the resulting PANi– AuAMNPs-Ab2 were used as label for the preparation of immunosensor. NPG film was used as electrode substrate material to capture a large number of the primary antibody(Ab1), so as to increase of the electrochemical signal [78]. To detect tissue polypeptide antigen (TPA), multifunctional graphene nanocomposites (Au@MGN) were designed as labels to achieve a high sensitivity and low limit of detection (LOD), which dominated the dual signal amplification strategy, because on one hand, introduction of graphene could accelerate the electron transfer capability of magnetic graphene nanocomposites (MGN) than single ferriferrous oxide nanoparticles (Fe3O4 NPs) and on the other hand, introduction of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) could build a synergetic effect between Fe3O4 NPs and AuNPs,which resulted in the increasing of electrocatalytic properties of Au@MGN [100]. For electrochemical aptasensor for the detection of thrombin, Au NPs decorated graphene sheet (Au@GS) and CoPd binary nanoparticles (CoPd NPs) were developed and showed good catalytic properties toward the reduction of H2O2 [101].
3.3. Repeatability and stability improvement
The repeatability and stability are the other key indicators of biosensors. To improve these indicators, there are still two challenges in the study of electroanalytical bioassays. First is looking for mimic enzyme instead of horseradish peroxidase (HRP). For designing electroanalytical biosensing strategies, themostly used signal response medium is H2O2reduction systembecause of its lowoxidation potential and inexpensive reagent consumption and moreover H2O2 is one of the most important analytes nowadays [102]. However, due to the short shelf life and easy deactivation of the biosensors using HRP, much inconvenience is brought for use of the biosensor. As we stated previously, various nanomaterials with different composition and dimensional morphologies could play the role as mimic enzyme instead of HRP, and based on the robust character of non-biologicalmaterials, the electroanalytical biosensor has good repeatability and stability. Among the mimic enzyme, noble metal and alloy nanomaterials may be the most used for fabricating biosensors due to their high catalytic and biocompatible properties [62,65,78–79,86]. For instance, bimetallic nanocrystals (NCs) with core-shell structures have received tremendous research interest because of their prominent catalytic activities and stabilities over monometallic NCs [48]. It is known that the properties of NPs could be readily influenced by tuning the size, shape, and composition of NPs catalysts. Au@Pd core-shell nanoparticles prepared by a seed-mediated synthetic method show dramatically enhanced catalytic activity, and have beenwidely studied because of their excellent catalytic efficiencies for a variety of chemical reactions [54,86]. In particular, Au@Pd coreshell nanoparticle catalysts provide a higher electrocatalytic activity toward H2O2 reduction than Pd or Au nanoparticles.
To further reduce the cost of the biosensor, nanomaterials of noble metal loaded on other materials are another most studied mimic enzyme. For example, Pd/SBA-15 [85,90], Au/Fe3O4 [93], AuPd/GS [67]
ectroanalytical biosensors: A mini review, Journal of Electroanalytical
are applied for fabrication of electroanalytical biosensors and shown excellent electrochemical catalytic properties.
Although the mimic enzyme can improve the repeatability and stability, the enzyme plays key role in many place, especially for medical diagnosis. So the second challenge is improving the repeatability and stability of the enzyme-linked biosensor [103]. In our study, due to many porousmicro- or nano- composites could applied as electrochemical supercapacitor and exhibited effective supercapacitive characteristics, we synthesized several mesoporous or porous micro- or nanomaterials, such as nano/microstructures NH4CoPO4 [50], nanoporous Co/Co3O4 [104], nanoporous NiGd-Ni2O3-Gd2O3 alloys [105], and mesoporous carbon [24] etc., and applied for fabricating electroanalytical biosensors. The good repeatability and stability may be attributed to the porous of thesematerials, which sometimes have the property of capacitor. For instance, the vital role of NH4CoPO4 for stabilizing the ECL signal in the preparation of the immunosensor was investigated [50]. If the matrix filmwas prepared without NH4CoPO4, the ECL signals were continue to decrease. However, when NH4CoPO4 was used to synthesis the matrix film, the intensities of ECL signal were stable after third periods. So, this phenomenon maybe owe to the effective supercapacitive characteristics of NH4CoPO4with hierarchical architecture, whichmight improve the ion movement and electrolyte access due to the many nanogaps assembled by nanoplates. Therefore, NH4CoPO4 as substrate is used for delayed release of the electrons and stable the ECL system.
4. Conclusions: challenges and outlook
Herein we have summarized the main role of nanomaterials playing in the preparation of electroanalytical biosensors. A variety of works above demonstrate the broad potential of nanomaterials can remarkably improve the important performance indexes of biosensors, such as sensitivity, selectivity, stability and repeatability. These strategies included the use of nanomaterials as supporter for loading probe, biomolecules (e.g., antibody, enzyme and DNA) and signal molecules (e.g., metal ions and electronic mediators) to enhance the sensitivity and promote selectivity, as mimic enzyme for efficiently electrocatalyzing many catalytic events and as loading matrix for stable signals response to improve the stability and repeatability. In the next few years, several techniques will continue to revolutionize various fields, such as new enzyme fixed technology and materials for reducing the loss of the immobilized enzyme activity, the direction of high flux, miniaturization (e.g., array sensor) for combination with other analytical techniques system and new sensors (e.g., aptamer biosensor) for realizing high selectivity and specificity.

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 29 April 2016 Received in revised form 16 August 2016 Accepted 6 September 2016 Available online xxxx Nanomaterials have beenwidely applied in the preparation of electroanalytical biosensors. Due to their small size effect, quantum size effect and surface and interface effect, nanomaterials can remarkably improve the important performance indexes of biosensors, such as stability, repeatability and sensitivity. Furthermore, as a result of different composition,morphology and size of all kinds of nanomaterials, they play the different roles in the process of the construction of the biosensors. In this review, the role of nanomaterials in electroanalytical biosensors used as the main line, a summary of 105 articles generalizes the main research achievement of electroanalytical biosensors. © 2016 Elsevier B.V.
